repnme.cdata!:
Nicaragua - Second Rural Municipal
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Second Rural Municipal
            Development Project for Nicaragua were as follows: outcomes
            were moderately satisfactory, the risk to development
            outcome was moderate, the Bank performance was satisfactory,
            and the Borrower performance was also satisfactory. Some
            lessons learned included: The inclusion of the municipal
            environmental management component was initially criticized
            for being an add-on (i.e. putting two projects in one).
            However, the emphasis on decentralized, local, and municipal
            action in all the three of its subcomponents (municipal
            environmental investment through a dedicated fund, Municipal
            Environmental Facility (FAM); support for municipal
            environmental management through legal staff working with
            municipalities and development of municipal councils; and
            creation of an environmental information system with
            municipal and Non-Governmental Organization (NGO)
            participation) was a key element to their success. It is
            quite likely that without being linked to a larger effort in
            support of decentralization to municipalities, these efforts
            would not have developed so effectively. Also assisting in
            the success of these efforts was: (i) consistency and
            effectiveness in the leadership of the involved ministry,
            Ministry of Environment and Natural Resources (MARENA); and
            (ii) consistency and effectiveness in the supervision by the
            Bank of the most complex of the subcomponents, National
            Environmental Information System of Nicaragua (SINIA), which
            received substantial input from one specialized Bank staff
            member throughout the life of the project. The participation
            of volunteer organizations particularly youth was
            unexpectedly very effective as they became partners in
            solving some of the environmental problems and establishing
            environmental programs. Many persons interviewed recommended
            that any future projects spend significant investments in
            environmental education combined with small grants to carry
            out citizenship programs. One key ingredient for success was
            the participation of Nicaraguan Association of
            Municipalities (AMUNIC)  in several aspects of the project
            (training, municipal plans, environmental commission, etc.)
            that ensured the continuity of many of the programs despite
            political changes which resulted in leadership and staff
            changes in municipalities and national government alike. In
            particular, AMUNIC played a strong role in the environmental
            agenda with its environmental unit staffed with highly
            qualified staff.

Nicaragua - Second Rural Municipal

repnme.cdata!:
Nicaragua - Second Rural Municipalities
            Development Project : proposed amendment to the credit agreement

abstracts.cdata!:
This proposal seeks approval to amend
            the Credit Agreement for the Nicaragua Second Rural
            Municipal Development Project (Credit 3480-NI). The Republic
            of Nicaragua has requested this amendment be made to reflect
            the enactment of Law 466 of Municipal Budgetary Transfers,
            in August 2003. This new Law created an environment more
            conducive to the accomplishment of the project development
            objectives. The proposed modifications will allow the
            Project to go beyond the original objectives to assist the
            Government of Nicaragua to implement a comprehensive legal
            and institutional framework for decentralization. The report
            recommends (a) creating a new component in order to support
            the decentralization reform; (b) expanding Project coverage
            to all municipalities (with the exception of Managua); (c)
            extending the original Closing Date for eighteen additional
            months to allow the Borrower sufficient time to implement
            the additional activities.

repnme.cdata!:
Nicaragua - Second Rural Municipal
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project objective of the Second
            Rural Municipal Development Project for Nicaragua is to
            improve the performance of rural municipalities by building
            their capacity in three major areas in which municipal
            governments can make a crucial contribution to sustaining
            rural development: providing local public infrastructure and
            the delivery of municipal services; protecting the
            environment and the sustainable management of natural
            resources; and promoting local economic development. There
            are two project components: municipal development and
            municipal environmental management. The first component
            includes four sub-components, which are decentralized
            financing, strengthening municipal institutions,
            strengthening the Nicaraguan Institute for Municipal
            Development (INIFOM), and evaluating and developing policy.
            The second component includes three sub-component, which are
            decentralization of environmental management, environmental
            information systems, and environmental municipal facility.

repnme.cdata!:
Nicaragua - Second Rural Municipalities
            Development Project - summary of environmental analysis and
            mitigation plan

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Rural Municipal Development
            Project poses environmental risks, namely associated with
            some subproject categories to be financed through a
            decentralized financing facility, i.e. the Municipal
            Development Fund (FONDEM), and by a municipal environmental
            facility (FAM), and are subject to compliance with
            Nicaragua's environmental regulations. This summary of
            environmental analysis, and mitigation plan includes a
            checklist to classify subprojects into two categories,
            namely category I, where no impact is identified, to be
            reviewed by the Technical Environmental Unit, and, category
            II where minor environmental problems are identified, thus
            requiring a limited environmental review, to be conducted by
            the Technical Environmental Unit, and the Ministry of
            Natural Resources and the Environment (MARENA). However,
            those subprojects that fall under category III, i.e., with
            irreversible environmental impacts, will not be financed
            under FAM. The summary identifies the steps to be taken in
            selecting subprojects: targeting, and promotion to ensure
            environmental issues are introduced in project
            implementation; project formulation to ensure environmental
            issues are introduced to project implementation; appraisal,
            to ensure environmental screening, and mitigation has been
            addressed, particularly that contract clauses have been
            enforced; and, monitoring, and evaluation to assess
            environmental screening, and mitigation procedures. Detailed
            mitigation plans are described in the Operational Manual.

Nicaragua - Second Rural Municipalities
